awd_titl_txt: Simulation of Singlet Oxygen Kinetics for Trace Organic Transformation in Wastewater Effluent
awd_abstract_narration:
Water resources in dry regions are stressed by drought and population growth.  Wastewater reclamation can provide an additional source of water for these areas.  However, trace contaminants such as pharmaceuticals that are not removed during wastewater treatment may pose ecological and/or human health concerns.  This project will provide new information on the role of sunlight in destroying potentially toxic trace contaminants, addressing the national need for sustainable, low cost and energy efficient technologies for water treatment.  Results will inform design of wastewater reclamation treatment systems in water-stressed areas.  The project will take advantage of programs at the University of Arizona to augment educational activities among disadvantaged students in STEM areas.  If successful, this project will provide valuable information on how to remove potentially harmful pharmaceutical and other contaminants from wastewater to allow its safe re-use in areas where water security is threatened. 

Solar-driven processes involving effluent organic matter (EfOM) generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) that contribute to transformations of trace organic contaminants (TOrCs).  For an important subset of TOrCs, a reaction with singlet oxygen is the dominant natural reaction pathway in treated wastewater.  It is not yet possible to provide a physically accurate representation of that pathway or the kinetics of indirect photolytic transformations of TOrCs by singlet oxygen.  Areas of uncertainty include (i) the dependence of quantum efficiency for singlet oxygen generation on light wavelength, (ii) the identities and concentrations of sensitizers in EfOM that participate in generating singlet oxygen, (iii) reaction rate constants for many TOrCs with singlet oxygen, and (iv) the toxicities of ROS-generated transformation products.  The primary objective of proposed work is to support the development of a robust and physically accurate kinetic model for the light-driven degradation of TORCs via reaction with singlet oxygen in treated wastewater.  The proposed research will use mathematically-supported methods to eliminate or minimize uncertainties in the photochemistry of singlet-oxygen-dependent mechanisms for TOrC transformations in treated wastewater.  More specifically, the work is designed to expose (i) the concentrations and characters of EfOM fractions that serve as sensitizers in the singlet oxygen pathway, and (ii) the dependence of quantum efficiency for singlet oxygen on light wavelength.  Results will support development of improved kinetic models that are potentially useful for reactor design in advanced wastewater treatment systems.  Next generation models based on bulk organic characteristics in EfOM and quantum efficiencies normalized to dissolved organic concentration are necessary to overcome deficiencies in state-of-the-art kinetic representations that are necessarily conditional in character.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Drought and population growth are placing greater strain on water resources in arid and semi-arid regions and driving increased interest in potable reuse as a method to augment water supply.  However, many trace organic contaminants (TOrCs) are incompletely removed by conventional wastewater treatment and are therefore discharged to the environment where they may then pose potential health or ecological concerns.  If this water is to be reused for potable (drinking) purposes, additional treatment processes are needed to ensure safety.  One possible additional treatment step is exposing treated wastewater to sunlight, which can initiate a sequence of chemical reactions in water that may effectively remove or degrade many TOrCs of concern.  This project examined an important type of sunlight-driven reaction where sunlight reacts with dissolved organic matter in the water to create a short-lived species of oxygen called singlet oxygen that can react with and degrade/destroy TOrCs.  We performed laboratory experiments to 1) test if this reaction process can destroy different TOrCs known to be present in treated wastewater, 2) determine level and speed of reactivity of a suite of TOrCs with singlet oxygen, and 3) develop a mathematical model to predict the effectiveness of sunlight in destroying different TOrCs via the singlet oxygen reaction mechanism.  

Through a combination of laboratory experiments and field activities, we found that 1) singlet oxygen is usually, but not always, the primary means of TOrC transformation in waters containing effluent organic matter, 2) sunlight can directly react and degrade some TOrCs, 3) both effluent organic matter and natural organic matter can react with sunlight and produce singlet oxygen, and 4) dissolved organics that are high in molecular weight and more aromatic are most responsible for initiating singlet oxygen production and TOrC transformations.

This project expanded our knowledge of TOrC transformations during the singlet oxygen reaction pathway.  Specifically, using experimentally obtained data, we 1) developed a kinetic model to describe TOrC photodegradation via singlet oxygen, 2) expanded the library of singlet oxygen photodegradation rate constants for several TOrCs, and 3) developed a quantitative structure activity relationship model to predict singlet oxygen reaction rate constants for TOrCs.  Project findings will be useful to improve engineered water treatment processes, as well as to assessing TOrC attenuation in natural waters, such as during river transport. Project results and model development will support efficiency improvements of potable water reuse engineered treatment processes for augmentation of water resources in water-stressed areas.

This project provided training opportunities for ten graduate students to learn and develop laboratory research skills including experiment design, lab safety, sample preparation techniques, analytical techniques for aqueous-phase trace organic contaminants, and data analysis methods.  Fifteen undergraduate students, including two NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates students, participated in laboratory and field activities under supervision of graduate students and project investigators.  Several peer-reviewed publications are in development and five presentations on project findings have been delivered to date at national professional society meetings, including two presentations at the American Chemical Society Spring Meeting in 2022.

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2022
Modified by: David Quanrud

Image
  • Schematic of indirect photolysis mechanisms that may break down trace organic contaminants in water.
    David M Quanrud
    David Quanrud
    Indirect photolysis mechanisms
